title: Reforming Health Systems: Using Data to Improve Health in Low- and Middle-Income Countries
xlist: Same As: HPM 580, section 01
description: Health systems in low- and middle-income countries are in constant flux in the face of myriad pressures and demands. Under such conditions, how can senior country officials and their donor partners make the best decisions to reform health systems to achieve Universal Health Coverage and to improve the allocation of resources to maximize health gains? The course rounds out and reinforces the Yale M.P.H. experience in the Global Health concentration by providing students with a thorough understanding of health systems and health reforms—their components, dynamics, performance, and impacts—and by imparting the key tools and data sources needed to conceptualize and assess options related to health system reform and resource allocation, and to make coherent and effective policy and financing recommendations. Using these analytical frameworks and techniques, students analyze 6–8 case examples of major country reforms and prepare two short policy papers applying what they have learned to real-world health systems challenges. This course is the capstone for the Global Health Concentration.
